confession.seduction_context: Very angry after husband had beaten her. Devil appeared, then vanished. 3 days later came again, said she was a poor woman and he would make her rich. Money turned into oak leaves.
sabbat_activities: dancing back to back to sound of flute
ate unseasoned meat like that of chickens
talked of killing people and doing harm

testimony.quarrel_subject: post she had taken from his field
various minor disputes with his first wife
testimony.threat_quote: qu'elle estoit bien haulte, mais qu'elle rabasseroit

witnesses.name: Bablon femme Jean Mathieu de Moyenmoustier
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor, mother-in-law of Urbain le Souche

testimony.quarrel_subject: told off her son Nicolas for not taking animals out early enough as herdsman
did not want to receive her in his house
testimony.threat_quote: qu'il en avoit encore des bien jeunes, et que d'icy a cinquante ans il ne scavoit ce qu'ilz deviendroient

harms_alleged.target: Fleuratte (daughter, wife to Nicolas Andreu mayeur)

testimony.quarrel_subject: bought land from tutor of dead sister's children, she was angry
told off his 5-year-old daughter Epnate for something she said
told her and her children off for taking wood from his field

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Catherine femme Jean le Maire or Marion femme Jean Voirin
Catherine femme Jean le Maire or Marion femme Jean Voirin

testimony.quarrel_subject: disputing with daughter-in-law Claudette who called her witch

witnesses.name: Beniste femme Colas Jean Mongeay de Moyenmoustier

testimony.quarrel_subject: husband lost sack, taken by son of accused

timeline.subject: procureur d'office
timeline.details: Procureur notes evidence received at request of Jean Jacquat 'partie produisante'. Orders arrest or banishment if she does not answer summons on three separate days.

timeline.subject: Change de Nancy
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves arrest order

timeline.subject: Catherine femme Jean le Maire
timeline.details: First interrogation. She denied all charges. Arrested in comté de Salm in bishopric of Metz.

timeline.subject: Catherine femme Jean le Maire
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses. Called them 'larron', 'faulcaire', accused them of lying.

timeline.subject: Catherine femme Jean le Maire
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture. Withstood thumbscrews but confessed when racked.

timeline.subject: Catherine femme Jean le Maire
timeline.details: Repeated confessions twice, asked to be put to death as soon as possible

timeline.subject: Catherine femme Jean le Maire
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

accomplices_named.name: Babillon femme Mongeon Voirin dit Masteste
accomplices_named.context: Recognized at sabbat at Haulte Pierre

accomplices_named.name: Jennon femme François Vanier
accomplices_named.context: Recognized at sabbat at Haulte Pierre

prior_accusations.context: Accused Catherine before her execution the previous year (1617). Catherine was not confronted with her.
Named Catherine as accomplice before her execution

notable_quotes.speaker: Urbain le Souche (to his wife about Catherine)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle estoit bien haulte, mais qu'elle rabasseroit
notable_quotes.english: that she was very haughty, but that she would be brought down
notable_quotes.context: Threat given to Urbain's first wife during minor disputes 18 months before trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Pieron (to Catherine)
notable_quotes.english: he would find her again/catch up with her
notable_quotes.context: After quarrel about post she took from his field, implied threat if he had misfortune

notable_quotes.speaker: Colas Collin (Catherine's threat)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il en avoit encore des bien jeunes, et que d'icy a cinquante ans il ne scavoit ce qu'ilz deviendroient
notable_quotes.english: that he still had some very young ones, and that in fifty years he did not know what would become of them
notable_quotes.context: When he refused to receive her in his house

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Mongeon's daughter Fleuratte
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle craindoit fort ladite prevenue, et qu'elle tascheroit de la contanter de ce que parfois elle luy demandoit de la maison
notable_quotes.english: that she greatly feared the said accused, and that she would try to satisfy her regarding what she sometimes asked from the house
notable_quotes.context: Fleuratte's fear of Catherine during her illness before death

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine's husband Jean le Maire (to Vincent Harmant)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il scavoit mieulx ce que s'estoit d'elle, qu'autres personnes qui en parloient, et qu'il vouldroit qu'elle fust desja bien loing
notable_quotes.english: that he knew better what she was than other people who spoke of it, and that he wished she was already far away
notable_quotes.context: Drinking and discussing rumors of her arrest, fortnight before trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine (when asked about St Dié trip)
notable_quotes.french: Elle a commencé a souspirer et estre affrontée sans dire mot, enfin elle a dit que c'estoit pour achepter des souliers
notable_quotes.english: She began to sigh and be embarrassed without saying a word, finally she said it was to buy shoes
notable_quotes.context: During interrogation, suspicious behavior about trip to St Dié

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine (to witnesses during confrontation)
notable_quotes.french: qu'ilz sont tous dampnés a tous les diables ceulx qui ont deposé
notable_quotes.english: that all those who deposed are damned to all the devils

notable_quotes.speaker: Richard Jean Collate
notable_quotes.english: husband called her witch and said she ought to be burned
notable_quotes.context: Several times heard her husband call her witch

relationships.evidence_text: resided with previous witness, who was her son
his daughter Fleuratte, wife to 'nous mayeur'
his daughter Fleuratte, wife to 'nous mayeur' (Nicolas Andreu mayeur)
Nicolas Andreu married Nicolas Mongeon's daughter
during lifetime of his first wife

economic_context.details: Multiple property-related quarrels: Jean Pieron quarreled over a post she took from his field; Nicolas Andreu told her off for taking wood from his field; Demenge Jacquat bought land from tutor of her dead sister's children and she was angry; witness 20's husband lost a sack taken by her son. Catherine transferred property to husband before fleeing. Economic status: poor (manoeuvrier's wife), feared dearth.

harms_catalog.harm_description: died suddenly
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: cow damaged her garden, wife warned about it

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill and died as if rabid, generally thought to be bewitched

harms_catalog.harm_description: deaths

harms_catalog.harm_description: sickened and died in the day

harms_catalog.harm_description: found dead in stable, stable door flew open on its own, heard noise of cats on roof

harms_catalog.harm_description: died after a strange illness which lasted a month, feared accused during life
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: either refused something or heard of suspicions

harms_catalog.harm_description: troubled by crows which flew down in front of them every time harnessed, great difficulty getting them out to work, lost much time
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: bought land from tutor of dead sister's children, she was angry; her daughter told him he would have done better not to buy them

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill, in pitiful state for 3 or 4 weeks before recovering gradually
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: told off his daughter for something she said, saying she would repent

harms_catalog.harm_description: 'fort enflé et plain de poison', generally reckoned to be bewitched

Nicolas Andreu told her and children off for taking wood from his field

used yellow powder in a pear to cure Mongeon Jean's daughter
annual offering at St Jean to be excused sabbat attendance

Urbain le Souche took an axe intending to attack accused
danced at sabbat to sound of flute
ate at sabbat, like that of chickens

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial, accused's residence
Sister executed there; she was more feared in ban d'Etival than her sister
Trip to sign act transferring property to husband; claimed to buy shoes
In bishopric of Metz, where she fled and was arrested
Location of Jehennon femme Claudon Veltin who named her as accomplice
Chretien Jean Barbe of Saulsure said she had been in his house
Sabbat location, carried there on master's shoulders
Sabbat location where many witches attended
Husband sent her to work in woods with 'bocquillons'
She took post from his field
Cow did damage in her garden; Colas Andreu's pig damaged her garden
Stable door flew open, cow found dead

economic_hardship_indicators: feared dearth (refused to make hail because poor and feared dearth)
devil promised to make her rich but money was oak leaves
transferred property to husband before fleeing
religious_calendar_references: St Jean (annual offering of chicken to be excused sabbat attendance)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean Voirin declared suspicions openly, was threatened and had to make 'une declaration amiable'

hearsay_chains.reporter: Bablon femme Jean Mathieu de Moyenmoustier
hearsay_chains.content: repeated essential of his testimony about losses

hearsay_chains.reporter: Bablon femme Jean Mathieu de Moyenmoustier
hearsay_chains.content: said she had been in his house since previous Wednesday
heard husband say he thought she might have gone with her son-in-law Denis who was a vagabond
heard Demenge du Maillé blame her for death of a pig
heard her disputing with daughter-in-law Claudette, who called her witch

emotional_state_notes: began to sigh and be embarrassed without saying a word when asked about St Dié trip
said she wished they had killed her already
asked to be put to death as soon as possible
full of regret during confession about death of Colas Andreu's wife

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: called Jean du Cellier 'larron de fruict' (fruit thief)
said Nicolas Mongeay had refused justice to her father-in-law Jean le Maire le viel while he was in office (he denied strongly)

third_parties.context: first husband before Jean le Maire

third_parties.context: also suspected for witchcraft; Nicolas Andreu thought losses caused by Catherine or Marion 'en hayne de quelques disputes'

third_parties.context: imprisoned on suspicion of witchcraft, Catherine said 'ce fust en homme de bien' (he was a good man)

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete extraction from 5-page PDF. Notable elements: (1) Catherine fled to comté de Salm to avoid arrest; (2) Her husband openly called her witch and wished she would leave; (3) She confessed to both harming and healing - used yellow powder to cure Mongeon Jean's daughter after making her ill; (4) Expressed remorse during confession about death of Colas Andreu's wife, said she was 'full of regret' but unable to cure her; (5) Father also imprisoned on witchcraft suspicion; (6) Sister executed for witchcraft; (7) Named as accomplice by two previously executed witches; (8) Economic status clearly poor - manoeuvrier's wife, feared dearth, devil's money turned to oak leaves; (9) Property transfer to husband before fleeing suggests attempt to protect assets; (10) Witness 16 (Nicolas Andreu) uncertain whether harms caused by Catherine or Marion femme Jean Voirin, another suspected witch; (11) Multiple witnesses report reputation of 10-20 years; (12) Confession obtained under rack torture after withstanding thumbscrews; (13) Asked to be put to death quickly, suggesting despair; (14) Change de Nancy approved both torture and death sentence without modification.
